column4: '~$ sudo e2fsck /dev/sdb1' reports at the end: "WD1.5_1: 2661/64004096 files." What do these 2 numbers mean?
used/available inodes              iirc
But inodes and files are different things. Can you elaborate.
check with sudo dumpe2fs -h /dev/sdb1 | grep "Inode count"
'~$ sudo dumpe2fs -h /dev/sdb1 | grep "Inode count" obtains: "Inode count: 64004096." This number is identical to the second "files" output by e2fsck.  --  Thank you very much for your help.
you can check with "sudo dumpe2fs -h /dev/sdb1" for free Inodes too. the difference should be the first number given by fsck
The difference is identical to the first e2fsck output number. As you predicted. --   Thank you very much again for your help.
port 53, dns
What do you mean by "port" here in relation to DNS. Can you elaborate?
dns-request are done via port 53udp by default
like ssh uses port 22 or smtp port 25 by default
http://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Port_(Protokoll)  for further info
you could use nmap -sP <network>
you still could use nmap -sP <network>
I have cursorily read 'man nmap'. But I still do not know what to substitute for <network> in my case.
apt-file search says: seahorse-plugins: /usr/bin/seahorse-agent
same for the other 2 things (whatever it is)
Ah! I need installing the DEB program package »seahorse-plugins«.  --  Thank you very much for your help.
hint: learn to use apt-file, very helpfull
I prefer Synaptic and packages.ubuntu.com
then you should learn to use that. packages.u.c needs 2 secs to find the answer
search the contents of packages is what apt-file search does
My problem was that I had no idea that I might not have installed a certain DEB program package. I thought that there was a reshuffle in the GNOME package seahorse or similar.
info locale "man 7 locale"
